comments.commentBody: I too was a Lamborghini kid who parented two Lamborghini kids and, like your parents I know my children's natures and prepared as much as possible for the inevitable/probable/possible sudden crazy act that one of them would perpetrate. I put both of them in harnesses and had them tethered to an adult at all times. Others' opinions be damned. Today, they are alive and  doing well.

I was a Lamborghini kid-- I constantly took off so swiftly and without warning that ultimately my parents put me on a harness and a leash, and my mother had to endure passers-by commenting, "That's a child, not a dog." But if she hadn't done that, I'm almost certain I would have been seriously injured or killed at some point, and yes, possibly caused an accident affecting others. My mom had four other kids to watch. But here is the thing-- fairly early on my parents realized they had to take extra measures with me, and I'm pretty sure if we were at the zoo and I had said anything about crawling over a fence, both of them would have been all over me. And there's something I've been trying to figure out here-- one story I read said the father was at the zoo with the mother, but she is the one everyone is so viciously attacking--perhaps because her voice can be heard. I think she said exactly the right thing to keep the child calm. "I'm here. Mommy loves you."
Anyway, I've come to believe zoos reflect an archaic mindset, no matter how lush the enclosures become. Animals, especially the large, intelligent mammals, do not belong on display in captivity for our amusement.

There is no surprise here.  Students with Pell grants mostly comes from low income families and tend to be less than prepared for college.  The question that must be asked is why more and more students with these backgrounds are choosing to go to college and most would fail to graduate and be burdened with crushing debts.  These students and their families have no choice but to gamble with college and debts because manufacturing, semi-skilled, blue collars middle class jobs have largely disappeared from the American economy.  Tax policies have failed to re-distribute income in terms of social benefits such as job training, childcare, healthcare, and K-12 education and thus exacerbated wage stagnation and income inequality.  Attending college regardless of capability to learn and pay has become the only avenue for low income students and their families to climb the economic and income ladder.

You know that about her son, eh? The students were unharmed? Who the hell killed hundreds of them, then?

50 cents just isn't enough for your post.
Good theme for Monday or Tuesday. Puzzle was too easy for a Wednesday.
You don't need to be hunchbacked or have a broken bone to have osteoporosis.

Lei Yang case the good side, if investigating a death can be so labeled, is the investigating of the police officers involved, the family’s access to the autopsy that shows damage contrary to initial police report and the wife imitating legal action. Lei Yang was a respected individual with academic contacts i.e. solid middle class. Hope to see final coverage of this case with that rare occurrence of punished police brutality. Police should be more careful who they rough up ….

I disagree. I was the first in my family to attend college.  I had no help to prepare me for any facet of college life, and I attended a selective private school.  Once in college there were no remedial classes, and there shouldn't be, that's not what college is for. If you need remedial classes you have no business being in college, period. Go back to high school or community college and work harder. I worked like a dog in college, with two reading- and writing- intensive majors and a foreign language minor, in the era where papers still needed to be written on typewriters...much more labor intensive.  I got a few bad grades as a freshman, but I plowed on. Dropping out was not something I ever considered.  I am amazed at the lack of resilience of today's generation, where transferring and dropping out are the first responses to adversity.  Today plenty of schools have watered down the requirements for a degree.  A college degree is easy to get, but a college education is still hard to earn...it only comes after the application of great effort.  There are no shortcuts and it cannot be faked, because the result is no less than personal transformation.  If that doesn't occur, you didn't try hard enough.  Those who can't commit to do their best at college are fooling themselves and would be better off not going. The predatory lending practices that ensnare unmotivated and unprepared students should be outlawed.
Or consider the Chinese curse:  May you get what you desire, i.e., the Republican  nomination for president.

Or as Truman Capote would say, "More tears are shed over answered prayers than unanswered ones".
In other words, be careful what you pray for.

By the time he is done here, Mr. Trump's *BRAND* will probably be worth less than 25% of what it was going in
His cache' on FoxNews will be roughly equivalent to that of Herman Cain, Mark Ferrman, or OLI' North
Any more TV shows featuring him will air in the proximity of: PawnStars, DuckDynasty, or SwampPeople
His highest visibility will be as a frequent guest on Howard Stern

The only way to *rescue* the 'Trump' brand will be for his kids to have him committed to a mental institution, and then, his much better offspring can actually run the business in a manner that beats the ROI of a simple money-market account.

Donald Trump will rue the day he decided to run for president. Not only is his campaign imploding, but his many business ventures will start to lose money.
As political commentator David Corn pointed out, before his run for the presidency, Trump was best known as a builder of luxury apartments and hotels; as a successful business man. The people who bought his condos, and stayed in his hotels, didn't give a thought about his politics; he was not a politician. Now his toxic political campaign and his views of Latinos,
Muslims, and blacks will cause many of those well-to-do people who have lots of choices will avoid Trump properties and stay in other luxury hotels and condos.

As the Greeks said, "Those whom the gods would destroy, they first make mad."

Perhaps a more universal solution would be to have far more tenured faculty actually teach undergraduate courses. A university's reliance on cheaper, "nomad" adjunct lecturers who, in many instances only pretend to be qualified to teach undergraduates, is a scandal. This is especially true at many of the more elite institutions in this country.

Having said that, my congratulations to Lara for having cared and made a lasting contribution to her students' lives.

Fellow sidewalk pedestrians:
Cell phone users are likely to be hit by a car before the ever have any danger from "radioactive" cell phones.
Yikes!
Neil
And ... give a rat a cell phone and you've created a Couch Mouse!

Here is a link to the American Cancer Society's press release about this study:
http://pressroom.cancer.org/NTP2016

The release says this study is "good science, and "that it marks a paradigm shift." The ACS also says "gender differences often appear in carcinogenic studies, so the fact they show up here should not detract from the importance of the findings."

The study cost $25 million, took several years, involved 7,000 animals, and collected 40 tissue types from each. This was not a small study.
I know it's not legal for the makers of raloxifene to market it as preventing breast cancer, but apparently it can protect against some forms.

I take raloxifene (generic form of Evista) for my osteopenia, which is in a different class from the drugs discussed here.  Both of my parents had osteoporosis, and I am a slight person of northern European ancestry.  I chose not to take the drugs discussed in this article because I am already at risk for jaw problems.  Five years ago I had radiation for throat cancer, and one side effect can be osteoradionecrosis (bone death caused by radiation) of the jaw.  I know a number of folks online who have suffered the effects of this horrible condition.  But if you are not already predisposed to have jaw necrosis, drugs in the Fosamax class seem to be a help.  My mother, who took it with no ill effects, never broke a bone, but my dad, who didn't take anything for his bones, was eventually crippled when he broke his hip.
MAHALIA JACK and SON. :)

Impossible. As he established in his Clinton hunt, any time anything happens that in any way affects you, you are automatically responsible, and any attempt to distance yourself by claiming lack of knowledge is only you being unethical.
Liberals are a demanding lot, somewhat.

Nonsense, Liberals are so tolerant that we would have been delighted if Ken Starr could have practiced what he preached - i.e., perform to a level he demanded of others. He lacked the moral conscience to resign entirely.

So.....We continue to be disappointed but not surprised.

The last line of Marc Tracy's article states, 'The board condemned a university leadership that, it said, “created a cultural perception that football was above the rules.”'

Events in the tiny town of Dietrich, Idaho, as reported by The Washington Post, suggest that the 'cultural perception that football [is] above the rules' is a national problem, encouraging acceptance of bullying, violence, rape and worse.

That's an insightful thought. But if a (football) game is played, it must be possible to lose it. Similarly, if one is willing to accept the top job, one must be willing to do the right thing, even when doing the right thing entails personal loss or humiliation.

That price is not enough!!

Starr should not be teaching law at Baylor or anywhere else.

For those of you wondering why the law school will still employ him, I assume it comes down to money. As president and chancellor, Starr’s total annual compensation was in the $1 million range. Although he was removed from the presidency, he retained the chancellor position. That likely puts his compensation around $500,000.  When administrators return to the classroom, they often retain their salary. Now that Starr has stepped down as chancellor, I am sure his salary will remain deep into six figures, and well above that of his peers in the law school.  If Starr had remained chancellor, recruiting a new president would have been that much more complicated. Thus, Starr’s return to the law school is the price Baylor is willing to pay to put his presidency behind it.

So Inspector Javert is forced to resign. How fitting. Life imitates art. Let this be an example to all future Republicans who aim to tear down any Democrat or anyone they perceive as left of their center - politically, religiously, or intellectually - that they are hypocritical frauds.
And not even Catholic like most would like to focus on.
The ban on dancing ended several decades ago.
Well, at least they weren't dancing, there's that.

I think there is a difference between sexual aggression/violence and sexual predation. I read most of the report; I don't recall seeing the phrase "sexual predator."
Many colleges are dealing with sexual violence perpetrated by football players. Baylor, Tennessee, Vanderbilt, Idaho, Florida State, Ohio State, and on and on. I don't think these schools are purposely looking the other way when they recruit. It's a sociological phenomenon.

He's never had a conscience. And women have never been of any consequence to him. This is what is called poetic justice and the law of Karma. Disgusting that Baylor did not just fire him. But then that's how universities are.

Didn't sweep it under the rug. Hired a top law firm to investigate. Took the decision by the regents like a man. Resigned from the step-down position as chancellor. We should wait to see what becomes of his law-school landing; he might resign from it as well.
I'll take that bet.
